title: Magnetic field due to three current carrying wires

content.description: Three long, current-carrying wires are shown in the cross-sectional view above. The currents in wires <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are out of the page, and the current in wire <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is into the page. The currents in the wires have equal magnitude, and the wires are in the positions shown. Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is halfway between wires <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
